newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks end higher on property optimism.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks end higher on property optimism.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks bounded ahead to close Monday up, with the rally fueled by a turnaround in the Dow and an improved outlook for the local real estate market, brokers said.
"Wall Street turned around, so Hong Kong has a squeeze on the short positions, said Andrew To, dealing director at OSK Asia Securities.

The Hang Seng Index closed 200.07 points higher at 13,331.48 after touching a high of 13,361.24. Turnover was a robust HK$9.14 billion, well up on Friday's HK$6.97 billion, although inflated by share placements.
"The Dow Jones Industrial Average turned around so dramatically. Now it is trading about 100 points below the historical high. So the whole situation changed," added To.
The Dow ended 10.76 points up at 6,484.40 in volatile trade on Friday, gaining nearly 200 points in a week.
Brokers also said investors believed the government will now not take any action to cool down the Hong Kong property market.

Anti-speculation measures taken by the developers themselves, such as allowing only a number of limited companies to buy flats in each development, appeared likely to forestall direct government intervention in the real estate market.

The good response to Sino Land's sale of luxury residential properties over the weekend also cheered sentiment, brokers said. The latest sales price of HK$5,628 per sq ft was 15.3 percent higher than the price of units offered two months earlier.
Share placements by Sino Land and another property counter did not dampen market sentiment, brokers said.

Sino Land parent company Tsim Sha Tsui Properties placed 238 million shares at HK$9.13 each, netting Sino Land HK$2.12 billion after expenses. Sino Land closed down HK$0.30 at HK$9.30 after bouncing off a low of HK$9.15, while Tsim Sha Tsui Properties rose HK$0.30 to HK$15.20.
Kong Tai International placed 582 million new shares at HK$0.25 a share. The stock rose HK$0.16 to HK$0.39 on turnover of HK$296.65 million.

"Sino Land's fund raising has long been expected. It was just a matter of time, said Y.K. Fu, property analyst at Merrill Lynch, adding this placement was an isolated case and not the start of a trend of share placements by property firms.
The property sector led the rally, substantially outperforming the rest of the market.
New World Development put on HK$3.05 to HK$51.75 and Cheung Kong advanced HK$2.75 to HK$68.75.
